topic.title: Event Mask

body.p: This field indicates the type of event to count. There are 64 counters in each stack, each of which will increment based on the events masked in this field. Set each bit to logic 1 to enable the corresponding event. With the exception of the Posted TLP, Non-Posted TLP, and Completion TLP events, all events are monitored on the ingress port only. For a given event counter, only 1 bit in the event mask is allowed to be selected since since each event counter can count only 1 event at the same time

note.p: The mask register used by the performance monitor is completely independent of the masks used by AER or UEC.

entry.p: This is only relevant for Completion TLPs received with an Unsupported Request status. This is not an AER error
ECRC errors are passed by the switch and the PMON can count them
A received Malformed TLP flags AER and the PMON can count this
Receiver overflow error flags AER and PMON can count this
This is only relevant for Completion TLPs received with a Completer Abort status. This is not an AER error.
* Poisoned TLP error is counted at the ingress, but can be dropped if the egress P2P is configured to block poisoned TLPs.
Upon a surprise down event, logs in AER and counts if unmasked
See PCIe Base Specification of sources of Data Link protocol error
Switchtec can store 5 TLP headers for AER. If a 6th header arrives, the overflow bit in the P2P bridge configuration space is set.
For future use cases, not currently used

If a switch sends a TLP and does not receive an ACK, this timeout is flagged and counted. Since this is an "egress" event of switch sending something and not getting a response, it is marked as "detected at egress".
If the switch replays more than 3 times, this rollover is flagged and counted.
See PCIe Base Specification of sources of Bad DLLP
See PCIe Base Specification of sources of Bad TLP
See PCIe Base Specification of sources of Receiver Error
This error is only directed to AER if it is configured to do so. Otherwise the switch can simply count these messages (representing link partner sending messages to or through the switch)

row.entry: This error is only directed to AER if it is configured to do so. Otherwise the switch can simply count these messages (representing link partner sending messages to or through the switch)

entry.p: This error is only directed to AER if it is configured to do so. Otherwise the switch can simply count these messages (representing link partner sending messages to or through the switch)
The switch received a NAK (as a result of something like the switch sending a sequence number that didn't make it to the other end, a lost TLP, or a bad sequence number)
If the RST is configured to trigger on a TLP, this counter can be used to count the number of times the RST rule was hit
For future use cases, not currently used
These counters are always counted and do not need to be configured in the PMON but can be read out. Both ingress and egress counters are enabled to always count.
These counters are always counted and do not need to be configured in the PMON but can be read out. Both ingress and egress counters are enabled to always count.
These counters are always counted and do not need to be configured in the PMON but can be read out. Both ingress and egress counters are enabled to always count.

body.p: Note that each performance counter can only increment by 1 or 2 on a given clock cycle. Each performance counter is intended to provide precise counting of any one event type only. Count precision is lost when multiple event types are enabled simultaneously. For a given clock, there can at most be 2 distinct events for a given event type corresponding to a maximum of 2 TLPs being processed at the same time.
A counter only increments once per TLP, regardless of the number of mask bits that are enabled and "hit".
